WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?
A QUESTIONNAIRE

Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name ... Mrs. Martha Martin (nee Stilborn)
Address ... Ainslie, Sask.
Birthplace ... Darlington, Eng.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? ... 1902 ...
Where did you set up housekeeping? ... Pleasant Grove, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? ... Pleasant Grove, Sask.
For how many people did you prepare meals? ... Generally, 6-8 ...
How far was it to your nearest store? ... 3 miles ... nearest town was Pleasant Grove.
How often could a visit be made to the store? ... Every two weeks ...
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? ... flour; dried apples; apricots; prunes; sugar; corn starch (not); soda; salt; tea; coffee; sugar; oatmeal; tapioca; rice; soap; raisins; currants; peel; some spices; syrup; salt; molasses ...

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ... $1.89 ...

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of paper if more space is needed).

Vegetables often froze in winter in absence
of proper storage facilities & in adequate
homes.
Materials were bought in large quantities
and all clothes homemade with sewing machine. Almost
all soles & stockings were hand sewn by hand.
I had a homemade hat that cost $5.
Water for laundry was brought by barrel
from soft water lake nearby. Although water
was soft, homemade soap cracked, roughened,
we cleaned the hands.

First we traveled around the
district in a wagon drawn by oxen. In 1887
we got a team of ponies & a buckboard. In 1893
we started using horses for working the land.
21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details as possible.)

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying, preparing, and eating foods in other ways, including pioneer days in northern Indiana.

In the fall of 1867, we moved into a new house near the old one. We had a small garden and raised vegetables for our own use. We also had a cow and a pig. We used to make butter and cheese from the milk. We also had a small orchard with apple trees.

We stored our vegetables in barrels and kept them cool in the basement. We also had a small cellar where we stored potatoes and other root vegetables.

We used to make our own bread and cakes. We also had a small stove in the kitchen where we cooked our meals.

We started using kerosene lamps for lighting in 1893.
In 1892 we purchased a house in a town of about 500 people. We called it "Our House" and moved there in 1916.

In 1892 we purchased a democrat. It was drawn by a team of light horses we called drivers.
